data.title: One on the Central Route of the Camino Portugues
data.meta_description: Day twenty-one on the Central Route of the Camino Portugués was a day for digging deeply into myself and my Camino experience.
data.text:
Day Twenty-One on the Central Route of the Camino Portugués ~ O Porriño to Redondela, 15.3 Km (9.51 Miles)

Day twenty-one on the Central Route of the Camino Portugués was a day for digging deeply into myself and my Camino experience. Team Magdalena did this day and day twenty all in one stage.

It was an enormous 32 kilometer effort for everyone and it rained almost the entire time, especially later in the day. This was the worst time it could have chosen to rain, in time for the steep hill ascent into and out of Mos.

This day is also almost entirely on pavement, as you will see in the photos to follow. There was never a more appropriate Latin expression for this day, than the one the medieval pilgrims said to one another in passing to and from Santiago, in the quote below.

“E ultreia e suseia, Deus adjuva nos.” “Let’s keep going further; let’s keep going higher… God help us.” ~ Taken from Santiago in Love Blog

Please consider your own desires, ability and stamina before choosing to do this entire stage in one day!

Map and Stats of Day Twenty-One on the Central Route of the Camino Portugués

Here is my personal interactive Google map which I created from my uploaded GPS tracks. As usual you will find accommodations, cafés and supermarkets that I placed on the map for easy location.

I have taken literary license and split our one stage into two day's worth of articles (days twenty and twenty one). You may refer to day twenty for information on the first half of this stage.

If you are tech savvy, you may enlarge this map and download my GPS tracks for your own use if you so desire. Just click on the three dots in the upper right hand corner of the map.

Here is our elevation profile for the stage from O Porriño to Redondela. It includes the fabulous and steep climb to the Santiaguiño cross of more than 200 meters (650 feet), and the steep descent into Redondela.

Photo-Rich Travelogue of Day Twenty-One, Central Route of the Camino Portugués

(As a note to the reader, there have been recent changes to the route leaving O Porriño, so the initial photos are again, not from the original narrative, so they show sunny and bright photos!)

From the town center in O Porriño, at the roundabout by the pedestrian street and the official route from the south, take the second right and onto the Rúa Raminranes to head northward.

If you are coming from the municipal albergue from the west, it is the second left at the roundabout, onto the Rúa Raminranes. The roundabout is where the two routes join and where I begin the route on my map. It was difficult for me to spot the yellow arrow on the northwest corner in front of the brown building, near the street level in the photo below.

Walk 1/3 kilometer along the Rúa Raminranes, below, and pass the Hotel Azul on your right. I had to chuckle at the blue van with the yellow arrow, pointing the way!

Come to another roundabout and join the N-550 as it continues north, shown next. First, cross over to the east (right) side of the roundabout as the sign indicates. Pass the small Capela da Nosa Señora das Angustias on the other side (not pictured). There is a Gadis and a Lidl in this roundabout, if you need supplies.

About another 300 meters onward, come to the busy intersection with the A-52. Look for a waymark leading you to the right and onto this gravel path, below, that will take you to a pedestrian bridge that walks the pilgrim up and over the A-52 exit ramp.

After crossing the pedestrian bridge on a little loop, the Camino returns back to the N-550 and walks under the A-52.

Immediately after the overpass, the path takes a right turn, and walks under another exit ramp on the other side, through this tunnel.

It was here, before the tunnel, that Matt, Magdalena and Michal decided to stay on the N-550 all the way to Redondela, as a well-paved shortcut, avoiding the day's steep hill climb into Mos. Because the entire stage was so very long, it was the best choice for them all ~ definitely easier for a wheelchair as well. We said goodbye to them, hoping to meet up in Redondela on day twenty-one of the central route of the Portuguese Camino.

We turned left at the next intersection, after the tunnel, to join a quiet paved road that parallels the N-550, the Camiño Vello de Santiago as it travels northward, shown below.

The municipality of Mos supplied these lovely signposts to guide the pilgrimage traveler through its district. Here is the first one that we encountered, below.

After 2/3 kilometer on the Camiño Vello de Santiago, you take a left hand turn, westward onto the Rúa da Quiringosta. Pass by a water fountain, just before the turn. Come to the N-550 and cross over it.

Then, continue on this street for about another 600 meters, and follow the wooden signpost to turn right and northward, shown in the photo below.

Here is Miriam walking on the quiet, paved side road, heading north through the countryside.

For the first 1/3 kilometer on this road, it is nice and flat, and then a steady incline begins, becoming ever steeper until the crest of this hill, shown here.

Then the pilgrimage traveler gets a break on the brief downhill cruise. Enjoy it now while you can!

There is a slight uphill towards the next town of Veigadaña. The Albergue Santa Ana de Veigadaña is a bit more than 3/4 kilometer from the turn north, and about 3.1 total kilometers from the center of O Porriño. Here is a photo of it. It would be a practical stage to extend your day from Tui to here, for a total of about 20 kilometers. There is also a cafeteria here, for the pilgrim's convenience.

After the albergue, the street becomes the Camino das Lagoas, and actually heads down another hill for a brief period. So it isn't all uphill on day twenty-one of the central route on the Portuguese Way!

But then, the pilgrimage traveler begins a slow steady climb, though more countryside, following the wooden signposts towards the next town of Mos. The weather was turning worse. It was raining significantly again. It is 4.4 km into the day, when you take a left turn at the sign and onto the Camiño do Castro, shown below.

The sidewalks begin shortly after the turn as you enter the town of Mos.

A few meters after the sidewalks begin there is a vending area on your left.

And just beyond the vending area, there is a wonderful rest stop, surrounded by blooming spring wisteria at 4.85 kilometers total. There is a picnic table and a water fountain to fill your water bottles. It was way too rainy for us to dally out of doors! It is approximately 1.73 kilometers from the albergue in Veigadaña to this vending area and rest stop.

About 1/2 kilometer after the rest area, you join the main road into Mos. If you turn left here, you will find an accommodation called A Casa Dos Parladoiros,(expensive appropriate for a group of seven). If you turn right and stay on the Camino you will walk into the main town area and towards the municipal Albergue de Peregrinos Santa Baia de Mos.

After a few meters on the main road, you come to this intersection, just before the town church where you turn left and onto the pedestrian way, pictured below, called the Camiño da Rua. It is a steep climb into this charming village and through the heart of town.

Below is look-back of Rich walking up the pedestrian way, by the town cross. The albergue, is on his left shoulder, just after the cross. The albergue in Mos is about three kilometers from the albergue in Veigadaña, 5.8 km from the center of O Porriño. This is another practical stop after Tui, at approximately 23 km.

We walked slowly through town, and past the albergue. It is a very charming place in the mountains. This would be a lovely place to stay in to shorten your day from Tui.

Below is the albergue where we actually stayed on a different walk. It is very nice and you actually sign in at the large town hall, just before the cross, and behind Rich in the photo above.

Mos is one of those amazingly quaint towns that in recent years has exploded! There are several very inviting-looking cafés along this section. I am not sure why we didn't stop here. I suppose we felt we hadn't put in enough kilometers since our last stop. Plus I thought there were many more cafés not far ahead. I thought wrong.

There is a very steep street climb as you leave Mos with lots of benches for resting along the way on the Camiño da Rua. There was no rest for us in the rain!

I took a photo, looking back at Miriam and Borut on the steep climb out of Mos.

Almost at the top, the Camiño da Rua joins the Estrada Alto de Barreiros-Santiaguiño and after only a few more meters the top is marked by the Santiaguiño cross, shown below. Lo and behold, there was blue sky above the cross when we arrived!

It is only about 800 meters from the turnoff in Mos to the first high point of day twenty-one at the cross, though it feels like much longer! Relax, breathe and pay your tribute here! At this point you are about 6.4 kilometers into your day twenty-one of the central route from O Porriño!

Continue on the Estrada Alto de Barreiros-Santiaguiño. The Way feels long, flat and straight on this paved road, for about another kilometer through rural countryside that is not very interesting. At least it was downhill for the most part.

We walked by our first Galician old-fashioned granary, called an horreo (pronounced sort-of like the Oreo cookie) on day twenty-one of the central route of the Portuguese Camino.

The Camino leaves the Santiaguiño road, after the kilometer, and turns left onto a sandy lane for about 1/2 kilometer. (Judging by the number of construction workers here on the morning we left Mos on a different, misty day, this lane that recently was broken cobblestone, most likely will be paved soon!)

If you were to stay on the Santiaguiño road, a few meters to the right there may be an open café, called A Taberna.

Join the Camino Cerdeiriñas, here and walk up a hill and through a cluster of houses along the road at the Parque Cerdeiriñas.

In 300 meters, we joined the Santiaguiño road once again walking on it for less than 200 meters before joining a lovely path, one of the few short off-pavement sections, shown below. Walk the path for 200 meters and through this lovely forest.

Join the Santiaguiño road yet again. Walk on this road for less than 100 meters and cross a main road towards another path for a second off-pavement section, below right.

There is also a small historic chapel on your left, in the park with the picnic tables, just before the crossing, the Capela de Santiaguiño where you may wish to stop, below. It was closed when we passed by. It has a nice sculpture of St. James the Moorslayer above the door.

It is on this crossroad, that if you turn right OR left, you will come upon a café (consult the map above). We did not know this at the time, and it would have been a great place for us to stop, after about 8.85 kilometers from O Porriño. Look for the signs to the café Bar Casa Veiga and Las Cabañas before you enter the pathway. Again, I'm not sure why we didn't stop. Most likely because the cafés were too far off-Camino and we did not want to take any extra steps!

Also at this intersection you are at the highest point of the day of 280 meters, the Alto de Barreiros- Santiaguiño. It is all downhill from here.

In addition, at the corner where the pathway continues, there is a Roman mile marker and a sign, shown below, letting you know that the Romans used milestone markers to indicate distances every 1000 passus, or Roman double steps. This was called a Roman mile or Miliario. Interesting!

After about 1/3 kilometer on the off-road path we turned right and picked up the Igrexa-Vilar Infesta paved road to walk toward the next town of Vilar de Infesta. Stay to the right and continue northward at the next Y-intersection.

Here is Magnus, walking through the town. It is a long way on sidewalks, through Vilar de Infesta, about 1.2 kilometers. The town is just immediately east of the Vigo airport.

There are now several cafés along this road if you need them.

Next, you turn off the road, on a hard left by the restaurant Churrasquería Choles. It was pouring rain by now and we desperately needed a break at 10.5 kilometers into the stage. The restaurant was packed out. Not a single table available! It was a Sunday afternoon lunch hour.

So, we went back out to the porch where there were a few chairs scattered under the awning. We were told there would be no service here. We dived into our packs for snacks as it continued to rain around us. There were to be no hot beverages. It would just have to do. It was a good thing we didn't try to keep walking. It started to hail heavily a few minutes after we sat down! OMG! Could anything possibly be worse??

I could see the look of despair on everyone's faces. They were a reflection of my own feelings. Fortunately the hail abated as quickly as it came. After about 15 minutes we got up to walk onward. It was still raining, but our break was actually perfectly timed to avoid the hail! I actually felt grateful for that small miracle!

We trudged on through the rain and wet pavement for 3/4 kilometer after our break. No one was talking much. We just kept our heads down and kept moving. The photos, however, still make the Camino beautiful-looking, don't they?

We came to a country lane, turned right and walked on it for 1/3 kilometer.

Along the lane, we could see the steep drop ahead into Redondela far ahead. Almost there! My spirits lifted, but not that much!

The Way went from mud to rough pavement as we began the ever steeper descent into the next town of Padrón.

In 100 meters we came to a T-intersection and turned right and in another 100 meters turned left to pick up the aptly named Camiño Romano to walk into Padrón.

In a few more steps we passed the Albergue and Bar O Corisco at 12 kilometers total. You are now at 29.2 kilometers from Tui at this albergue, and 3 kilometers from Redondela. Just a thought! We trudged onward!

We considered for a moment stopping here for something hot, but since we were so close to Redondela we decided just to get the day over with!

The Camino continues on the Camiño Romano and walks by this country home. You can see the sun was now trying to break out, as the sky tried to brighten, as seen in this photo. Unfortunately, the sun did not break through, despite several attempts. The elevation has now flattened out as you can see, at least making the walking a bit easier.

The Camino walks about a total of 2.2 kilometers straight on from the turn onto the Camiño Romano until you reach the outskirts of Redondela, the scenery becoming more and more suburban-looking.

Here we are, joining the N-550, just south of the Redondela city limits. This is where Matt, Magdalena and Michal would have come into the city, after doing the entire route from O Porriño on this highway.

After about one-half kilometer, you turn off the N-550 to the right and onto the Rúa do Muro, where the Redondela sign is before you. We had finally arrived in Redondela.

If you were to stay on the N-550, in a few meters you would encounter the private Albergue A Rotonda, in the next traffic circle.

It took all I had to convince the guys to pose by the sign. I'm not sure where Miriam was during this photo, but she most likely was behind a bit, and I had no patience to wait to take the photo. All of us were totally spent. Even the young bucks!

The Convento de Vilavella loomed darkly in the dreary light on the other side of the street from us.

We walked onward a few more meters to join the Rúa Pai Crespo to walk into the center of town. There are many private albergues in Redondela, in my opinion, a not very attractive town. First pass by the Albergue Santiago de Vilavella, then the Albergue A Conserveira right along the Rúa Pai Crespo.

Along this street we left our friends in front of their accommodation. Matt, Magdalena and Michal had texted us their location, and the rest of our group wanted to quickly join them, have a hot shower and rest. We reluctantly said good-bye to Matt, Miriam and Borut, hoping and planning to meet up in Santiago in a week or so. It was a sad parting.

We have no photos of a wonderful communal happy hour or dinner at the end of day twenty-one of the central route on the Camino Portugués. For Rich and I, this was the end of our Camino Portugués.

With heavy hearts and heavy feet, we walked the final few meters along the Rúa Pai Crespo, after it takes a jog to the right, below, to the attractive municipal albergue in the center of town, the Albergue Casa Da Torre De Redondela, where I turned off my GPS, officially completing this stage.

We were headed to the train station to travel to the north coast to start the Camino Inglés with other friends. We had done the route from Redondela to Santiago only the prior year, and we were not going to repeat it this year. To see the rest of this route, please click on day twenty-two when we did it prior.

If you are staying in Redondela, there are several more prívate albergues clustered to the north of the municipal albergue, the Albergue A Casa da Herba, the Albergue Rosa D'Abreu, (Where I have stayed and do not recommend), the Albergue Alfonso XII, the Virginia Redondela (+34 660 58 95 15) and finally, the parochial Albergue Santiago Apostol de Redondela.

If you are looking for a hotel or pension instead, click on this link. Or maybe even better yet, walk right on by Redondela another 3.0 kilometers northward and have a choice of three accommodations, farther on in Cesantes, see day twenty-two. I never did find that Redondela had much to offer me.

Before going to the train station we looked for an open café bar on this dreary, late afternoon. We were horribly hungry. Of course, the whole town was closed for siesta. We finally found an open bar that only had tortilla bocadillos to eat. They filled our bellies. We washed the sandwiches down with beer to ease our pain.

Without a shower and without a rest, we called a taxi for the train station, getting ready for the next phase of our Camino. We would get to La Coruña late that night and we could rest on the train. We would have to wait to shower when we got there.

Reflections on Day Twenty-One, Central Route of the Camino Portugués

I am almost in tears as I write this, many months later, reflecting on the wonderful connections that we made, and how difficult it was to leave our friends in the middle of their journey to Santiago. The weather most certainly reflected our dismal mood.

The day was very difficult, as we had combined it with day twenty, to make a very long day in very wet conditions. I would not have chosen this, had it not been for our tight train schedule. In fact, I was even willing to release the money we had already spent for the train ticket, to alter our plans if needed.

As it turned out, Team Magdalena prevailed, even though the half with Magdalena went another way. It took quite a bit of digging deep, to get the two days accomplished, for all of us. Despite the difficulty of the long day, I found that I was not as dispirited as usual. I reflected on why this was so.

There was something a bit more special about this team that we had created than others, and the last six days were very powerfully motivating for me. It really was a very, very special time for both of us! I was very teary going into our Camino Inglés the next day as I missed our team so much already! I am not a very sentimental one, so this surprised me quite a bit!

When I had made these plans, many months ago, I did not realize the impact leaving a Camino family would have on us, if separated prior to the finish in Santiago! We were a powerful team together and I wondered later, how this would be replaced going forward.

Because of the long day, we did not have time to see Magdalena, Matt and Michal again. They had arrived in Redondela before we did, having taken the shortcut on the N-550. They were resting when we arrived and we did not want to disturb them. It was a terribly long day for all of us. We could only hope to see them later.

The good news is that we did at least see Magdalena and Matt again in Santiago, some days later. While the rest of team Magdalena had time constraints and arrived in Santiago several days before the rest of us, Magdalena and Matt had none! They took their time exploring the wonderful cities between Redondela and Santiago and because of it, we were able to connect in Santiago later.

We had a happy reunion in Santiago after we had completed our Camino Inglés, so the story has a happy ending!

Salutation

May your own day twenty-one of the central route on the Camino Portugués be filled with persistence and commitment to your personal journey, however that may look for you! Keep going further; Keep going higher… May God help you! E Ultreia E Suseia!

And the Journey Continues:

~ Lisbon to Porto

~ Porto to Santiago Via the Coastal Route and/or the Sendal Litoral
